headline.main: National Briefing | South: Florida: Number Of Obese Nearly Doubles

docs.abstract: Florida Health Department report finds number of obese Floridians increased 94 percent since officials began monitoring problem in 1986; finds 38 percent of adult Floridians are overweight, with 18.5 percent being obese; rate rose 82 percent among Hispanics, 65 percent among non-Hispanics and 51 percent among non-Hispanic blacks during 10-year period from late 1980's to late 1990's (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The number of obese Floridians has increased 94 percent since officials began monitoring the health problem in 1986, a state Department of Health report said. According to the study, 38 percent of adult Floridians are overweight; 18.5 percent are obese. The obesity rate rose 82 percent among Hispanics, 65 percent among non-Hispanic whites and 51 percent among non-Hispanic blacks during a 10-year period from the late 1980's to late 1990's. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has awarded the department $345,000 to initiate statewide efforts to control obesity. Terry Aguayo (NYT)
